advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT SEPT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> SEGA'S new hard keyboard and new hard disk drive, make Sega even harder to beat.<br> The very latest industry standard 3" diskettes store a massive 328K of information each desk, and operate at speeds far in excess of their older 5 1/4 inch counterparts. Sega's super control station will also enable you to connect to many other attachments such as business printers electronic typewriters even telephone moderns, through it's two additional I/0 ports, for RS232C and parallel interfaces. <br><br> Sega now boasts not only the most sophisticated and easy to learn basic language, the most incredible graphic capabilities, a sensational range of cartridge and cassette games, superb education and applications software written by and for New Zealanders, but also a very sophisticated, fast, small business system, with the state of the art Sega control station. Feel the difference, see the difference, compare the difference, and you too can enjoy the difference of Sega superiority.</font> <br><br> Notice that between numerous superlatives, the advertising agency mistook floppy disk for hard disk drive.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the traditional and strongly sterotyped promotional picture found on almost all 70s system boxes & leaflets... The whole family is there (parents and two children, a girl and a boy). They are drinking orange juice. Only males are playing, but girls are soooo happy to be allowed to watch the game...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Neurons' jogging"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SALES CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this catalog, NEWMAN COMPUTER EXCHANGE from Ann Arbor sold various Interact packages, from $44.95 for an incomplete and inoperative 8K model, to $299.95 for a 16K system along with 30 software cassettes and a complete documentation including the service manuals set. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHRISTMAS 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"><b> A smart investment</b><br> Radio Shack's popular TRS-80 Color Computer is now on sale. You can get this complete, versatile system with a 16 K-byte memory and Standard Color BASIC language for only $299.95 (Cat. No. 26-3004, reg. $399.95). It's the affordable way for the entire family to start computing.</font><br><br> The Extended BASIC - 16 KB version was priced $399.95<br> The 32 KB version was priced $549.95.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>

computer.description:
Little is known about this Slovak clone of the ZX Spectrum.
One of its particularity is that it has a separated reset button and two joystick ports (1 Kempston + 1 Sinclair). But both joystick ports have non-standard connectors.
The ULA (video chip) is different from the one used in the original Spectrum. It's a russian circuitry, and it results in the screen being square instead of rectangle. Because of these russian ICs, the Diaktik M was actually much more compatible with Russian Spectrum clones (like the Pentagons) than with original ZX Spectrum.
The Didaktik M seems to be sold as a 64 KB RAM computer but only 48 KB is available.
Two models of the Didaktik M were produced (90 & 91). The Didaktik Kompakt is in fact the same computer with a built-in floppy drive on the right side of the unit.
A 3 channel sound interface with ACB stereo called "Melodik" was also available, as well as a 3.5" external floppy drive called D80.
Didaktik M and Kompakt are still sold online here!
Richard reports to us: There was external 5.25" floppy drive produced called Didaktik D40. I think it was able to take memory snapshots with a snapshot key located on the connector to the floppy. Later there was Didaktik M Kompakt produced which had 3.5" floppy integrated on the right side of the unit. I used this computer to play games, was fun.
Predseda (Czech Rep.) adds: It has one of the most uncomfortable keyboards ever. Keys are unnacuratelly attached to the computer?s body and it makes their pressing really painful. Quick typing on its keyboard is really impossible, you must press each key separatelly and with special care.
and Petr adds: It has 4MHz CPU, different from original Spectrum and must be braked - some instructions has another size of tact. RAM is 64 KB but only 48 KB is used. There is no difference between slow and fast memory. This computer is much more compatible with Russian Spectrum clones than with original ZX Spectrum.
computer.keyboard: QWERTY mechanical keyboardwith separated arrow keysand many functions per key just like the spectrum
computer.name: M
computer.ports: Expansion busSinclair Joystick portKempston joystick portVideo output
computer.ram: 64 KB (48 KB used), up to 128 KB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DIDAKTIK M</strong></font><br><blockquote>Ditaktik M48 with its power supply unit <br><br> <b>Jan Hlavaty's</b> experience:<br> It was my first micro-computer. I bought it for 4000 CZK in 1996. It had an external power suply with same design as the main computer.<br> Games and aplications were recorded on magnetic tapes. We could use any tape recorder and connect it to the right connector. I also had the Tesla SP-201T cassete tape-memory unit along with a dot-matrix printer which required carbon-paper for printing! Then I bought a regular Elta cassete player and then a floppy disk drive unit (3500,- CZK!).<br> I played many ZX-spectrum compatible games. Many games were made in Czech Republic, the cost for one cassette game was about 350,- CZK.<br> Restart of the system was done by pressing CAPS SHIFT + RESET buttons. Each key featured 3 to 4 specific commands which was switched with the SYMBOL SHIFT or CAPS SHIFT buttons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="mailto:krizm@ssps.zcu.cz ">Martin Kriz</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> USER'S MANUAL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="mailto:krizm@ssps.zcu.cz ">Martin Kriz</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="mailto:krizm@ssps.zcu.cz ">Martin Kriz</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> TV aerial RF modulator<br> <b>(2)</b> TV aerial output plug<br> <b>(3)</b> Composite monochrome monitor output plug<br> <b>(4)</b> External power supply unit DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(6)</b> Z80A microprocessor labelled Zilog<br> <b>(7)</b> Spectrum compatible I/O connector<br> <b>(8)</b> 16 KB ROM chip holding Spectrum O.S. and BASIC interpreter<br> <b>(9)</b> Russian version of the Spectrum ULA (specialised chipset)<br> <b>(10)</b> Joystick connectors. Sinclair (right) or Kempston (left) compatible<br> <b>(11)</b> 64 KB russian chips RAM bank</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Sinclair joystick type connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Kempston joystick type connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Spectrum compatible system bus connector<br> <b>(4)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> Power supply DIN plug<br> <b>(6)</b> Monochrome composite video output plug<br> <b>(7)</b> TV aerial output plug</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The CPU and the ROM<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="mailto:krizm@ssps.zcu.cz ">Martin Kriz</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="mailto:krizm@ssps.zcu.cz ">Martin Kriz</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ULA CHIPSET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The russian version of the Sinclair Spectrum dedicated chipset. The original version was made by Ferranti in Italy. </blockquote>
